user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_response_from_fd_at_offset:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_from_fd_at_offset (size_t size,
                                       int fd,
                                       off_t offset)
{
  if (0 > offset)
    return NULL;
  return MHD_create_response_from_fd_at_offset64 (size,
                                                  fd,
                                                  (uint64_t) offset);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function MHD_create_response_from_fd_at_offset:
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_from_fd_at_offset64 (uint64_t size,
                                         int fd,
                                         uint64_t offset)
{
  struct MHD_Response *response;

#if ! defined(HAVE___LSEEKI64) && ! defined(HAVE_LSEEK64)
  if ( (sizeof(uint64_t) > sizeof(off_t)) &&
       ( (size > (uint64_t) INT32_MAX) ||
         (offset > (uint64_t) INT32_MAX) ||
         ((size + offset) >= (uint64_t) INT32_MAX) ) )
    return NULL;
#endif
  if ( ((int64_t) size < 0) ||
       ((int64_t) offset < 0) ||
       ((int64_t) (size + offset) < 0) )
    return NULL;

  response = MHD_create_response_from_callback (size,
                                                MHD_FILE_READ_BLOCK_SIZE,
                                                &file_reader,
                                                NULL,
                                                &free_callback);
  if (NULL == response)
    return NULL;
  response->fd = fd;
  response->is_pipe = false;
  response->fd_off = offset;
  response->crc_cls = response;
  return response;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if ( ((int64_t) size < 0) ||
       ((int64_t) offset < 0) ||
       ((int64_t) (size + offset) < 0) )
    return NULL;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The three tests cast uint64_t values to int64_t and check for negativity; these can be true at runtime (for example size = (uint64_t)INT64_MAX + 1 will make (int64_t)size < 0), so the return NULL branch is reachable. The earlier #if-guarded test may reject some large values in some builds, but that is conditional compilation — it does not make the later check unreachable in all builds. Therefore Rule 2.1 is not violated.
